name: BBCWorld
text:
Iran started to relax its coronavirus restrictions in mid-April, after the number of infections declined

It’s seeing a rapid surge in the numbers of coronavirus cases

Could it be facing a second wave of the pandemic?

[Thread] https://t.co/g7clbfcY9O

name: BBCWorld
text:
Iran started to relax its coronavirus restrictions in mid-April, after the number of infections declined

It’s seeing a rapid surge in the numbers of coronavirus cases

Could it be facing a second wave of the pandemic?

[Thread] https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/U2fNmsNWDE

name: BBCWorld
text:
The previous highest number of cases was 3,186 on 30 March when Iran was one the worst affected countries outside China

At that time, authorities were criticised for acting slowly 

The government eventually closed mosques, public parks and schools

https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/SmZoqdIs4j

name: BBCWorld
text:
The number of cases started to decline and in April it dropped to below 1,000 a day

At that stage Iran began to ease its restrictions by reopening:

Shopping malls 
City transport systems
Public parks 
Mosques 
Religious shrines
Restaurants, cafes, banks

https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/8pr79SvBjl

name: BBCWorld
text:
The epidemic was initially concentrated in Qom and the capital, Tehran

But now, a flare-up has been reported in the south-west, notably in Khuzestan province, an oil-rich region that borders Iraq

https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/Kr8C0NNY5B

name: BBCWorld
text:
New reported infections averaged more than 3,000 a day in the first week of June - a 50% increase on the previous seven days

The figure reached a high of 3,574 on 4 June, before dropping slightly

https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/c6TpFy9IQb

name: BBCWorld
text:
New reported infections averaged more than 3,000 a day in the first week of June - a 50% increase on the previous seven days

The figure reached a high of 3,574 on 4 June, before dropping slightly

https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/9WMHSauBh3

name: BBCWorld
text:
Why are Iran's numbers rising?

There is clearly more social interaction with the easing of restrictions - but officials have suggested the surge in new cases could be down to more testing

https://t.co/oYjt40673E

name: BBCWorld
text:
On 29 May, just under 11% of tests were positive - but by 6 June that figure had risen to over 14%

Health officials have also pointed out the number of daily deaths recorded has been below 100 since mid-April

https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/NWsE0Pdo69

name: BBCWorld
text:
The daily figure was between 30 and 90 for most of May, but on 14 June it went above 100

It would take several weeks after the initial rise in infections for an increasing trend in recorded deaths to become apparent
 
https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/WU0isFyqEg

name: BBCWorld
text:
According to the health ministry people are also ignoring social distancing rules:

• 40% of the population are keeping the social-distancing rules, down from 90% earlier in the outbreak

• 32% are following the rules on self-isolation, down from 86%

https://t.co/oYjt40673E https://t.co/ThGOw0dlov

name: BBCWorld
text:
Restrictions may have to be reintroduced if the outbreak worsens, but Tehran does not want to talk about a "second wave"

BBC's @ranarahimpour explains: "To contain the virus, you need a lockdown and in a lockdown, you need to be able to pay people"

https://t.co/oYjt40673E
